articles.headline: A Marine Looks Back at His Battles in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: In February 2010, in the Taliban sanctuary of Marja, we were fighting to let Afghanistan build a democracy. Or something like that.
articles.abstract: In February 2010, in the Taliban sanctuary of Marja, we were fighting to let Afghanistan build a democracy. Or something like that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, a Pentagon correspondent for The New York Times, served four years in the Marines and first deployed to Afghanistan in 2008, then again in 2009 at the beginning of the troop increase ordered by President Barack Obama.

articles.headline: During Kavanaugh Hearings, Senator Alerted F.B.I. to New Allegation
articles.snippet: A Democratic senator expressed concern last year that the F.B.I. was not following up on allegations against the Supreme Court nominee.
articles.abstract: A Democratic senator expressed concern last year that the F.B.I. was not following up on allegations against the Supreme Court nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the F.B.I. began looking into allegations of sexual assault against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh during his Supreme Court confirmation hearings last year, a Democratic senator wrote to the director of the bureau saying that he had “information relevant” to the inquiry, but that the F.B.I. apparently failed to follow up.

articles.headline: The Cost of Running Guantánamo Bay: $13 Million Per Prisoner
articles.snippet: Set up nearly 18 years ago to house detainees in the war on terrorism, the prison on the remote naval base has grown into what appears to be the most expensive on earth.
articles.abstract: Set up nearly 18 years ago to house detainees in the war on terrorism, the prison on the remote naval base has grown into what appears to be the most expensive on earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.

articles.headline: To G.M. Workers, U.A.W. Strike Is Chance for Overdue Reward
articles.snippet: Union members are pushing for what they see as a fair share of the company’s hefty returns, a decade after its bankruptcy, as negotiations continue.
articles.abstract: Union members are pushing for what they see as a fair share of the company’s hefty returns, a decade after its bankruptcy, as negotiations continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A decade ago, when General Motors was on the brink of collapse and was ushered into bankruptcy by the federal government, the company’s unionized workers bore a significant portion of the pain to bring the automaker back to financial health.

articles.headline: Andrew Yang Knows You May Disagree With Him About Shane Gillis
articles.snippet: Mr. Gillis was dropped by “Saturday Night Live” after making racist comments about Asian-Americans and using a slur to refer to Mr. Yang, a presidential candidate, who has urged forgiveness.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gillis was dropped by “Saturday Night Live” after making racist comments about Asian-Americans and using a slur to refer to Mr. Yang, a presidential candidate, who has urged forgiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shane Gillis, a 31-year-old stand-up comedian who was named last week to the “Saturday Night Live” cast, has mimicked caricatures of Chinese accents. He has called it a “hassle” to have to speak with a waiter in a Chinese restaurant. He has used a racial slur to refer to the entrepreneur Andrew Yang.

articles.headline: WeWork Delays I.P.O. After Chilly Reception From Investors
articles.snippet: The company’s parent has been trying to rescue the public offering amid concerns about the high valuation for a business that is deeply unprofitable.
articles.abstract: The company’s parent has been trying to rescue the public offering amid concerns about the high valuation for a business that is deeply unprofitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WeWork, the shared office space giant, gained the backing of some of the world’s top investors, but it received a much colder reception when it tried to sell its shares on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: To Find Clues in Saudi Oil Attacks, U.S. Examines Missile and Drone Parts
articles.snippet: American investigators are gathering evidence to bolster their claim that Iran was responsible for attacking oil facilities in Saudi Arabia.
articles.abstract: American investigators are gathering evidence to bolster their claim that Iran was responsible for attacking oil facilities in Saudi Arabia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American investigators are examining missile circuit boards recovered after strikes against Saudi oil facilities to determine the trajectory of the attack — and whether it originated from Iran — as the Trump administration debates how, and whether, to retaliate.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Cokie Roberts Dies; Veteran Broadcast Journalist Was 75
articles.snippet: She was known to millions for her pioneering work for ABC News and NPR.
articles.abstract: She was known to millions for her pioneering work for ABC News and NPR.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cokie Roberts, who drew on her upbringing in a powerful political family to fashion a career as a leading Washington journalist for NPR and ABC News, bringing a tough, knowledgeable voice to the rough-and-tumble political arena at a time when few women had national profiles in the news business, died on Tuesday in Washington. She was 75.
